newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Popular Taiwan official resigns ahead of reshuffle.
newsitem.headline: Popular Taiwan official resigns ahead of reshuffle.

text.p: A popular Taiwan cabinet member announced his resignation on Thursday ahead of a planned government reshuffle in response to growing public outcry over a spate of violent crime.

Ma Ying-chiu, minister without portfolio, said in a statement he had tendered his resignation to Premier Lien Chan "due to change of political ethics, obstacles in reforms and growing public discontent."

"Before the reforms can be achieved, political mores have already changed, with (officials) struggling for powers, taking credits and shunning responsibility," said the former justice minister, one of the most popular officials on the island.
Ma also quelled speculation that he planned to run for Taipei mayor.

The former justice minister had been tipped by the ruling Nationalist Party to run in the 1998 mayoral election against incumbent mayor Chen Shui-bian from the opposition Democratic Progressive Party.
Instead, Ma said he would join other private individuals and groups to promote social reforms and pursue academic studies.
"Taiwan is a pluralistic society... and reforms do not necessarily have to be led by the government," he said in a statement.
The premier's office said it had not received Ma's official resignation.
But Wu Poh-hsiung, secretary-general of the ruling Nationalist Party, said he would respect Ma's decision.

Public discontent over the government's failure to improve social order has erupted since police discovered the body of renowed actress Pai Ping-ping's teenage daughter on April 28, floating naked in a river.
Police said 17-year-old Pai Hsiao-yen was kidnapped and murdered. But the killers remained at large.
The murder followed a string of violent crimes that have occurred since 1996.
More than 50,000 people marched in Taipei on Sunday to protest against Pai's murder and demand the resignation of Lien and a cabinet reshuffle to take responsibility.
The protest prompted President Lee Teng-hui, who doubles as chairman of the ruling Nationalist Party, to call for a partial reshuffle of the cabinet on Wednesday.
Lien had also tendered his resignation to Lee, but was asked to stay on.
Lien was expected to deliver a list of reshuffled cabinet positions for approval during next Wednesday's central standing committee meeting.
